Skills load on-demand using progressive disclosure: at startup only name+description (~100 tokens) are loaded, full SKILL.md instructions (<5k tokens) load only when the skill is triggered. When documenting available skills in agent files, use brief pointers (name + one-liner) rather than duplicating CLI docs - the skill's full documentation loads automatically when invoked.

Design Language document created at docs/design/DESIGN_LANGUAGE.md. Bridges landing page expressiveness with daily-use tool calm. Key principles: (1) Character without chaos - personality in moments not everywhere, (2) Calm is not boring - restraint is intentional, (3) Clarity over cleverness, (4) Accommodate don't segregate. Defines typography (Anybody headlines, system-ui body, DM Mono code), color system (landing DNA as accents not backgrounds), spacing scale, and ND theme variations (dyslexia-friendly cream bg, autism-friendly muted/no shadows, high contrast). Integrates with openbadges-ui AccessibilityService for theme switching.

CSS custom properties (variables) fail silently when undefined. If you use `var(--space-5)` but never define `--space-5` in `:root`, the property simply doesn't apply - no error, no warning. Always verify design tokens exist before using them, or define fallbacks like `var(--space-5, 1.25rem)`.

Use `fill="currentColor"` on SVG paths to make icons inherit the text color from their parent element. This makes SVGs theme-aware - they automatically adapt to light/dark mode and can use CSS hover effects like `color: var(--accent-purple)` without needing separate SVG files or fills.

When removing auto-injection of knowledge context at session start, tests expecting formatted summary content need updating. The design now returns raw data (learnings, patterns, mistakes, topics) for consumers to format on-demand, with summary only containing workflow checkpoint state.

Hookify rules can extend plugin behavior by adding instructions to the same rule file. Instead of modifying official Claude plugins, you layer additional instructions on top via the rules system in ~/.claude/rules/.

Memory pressure during Claude Code sessions can be caused by verbose startup hooks that inject large outputs into context. The graph parse command creates 966 entities + 1910 relationships + 579 CodeDocs with embeddings during SessionStart, and all hook outputs are injected as system-reminders. Each hook's stdout becomes part of the context window.

claude-knowledge has two incremental indexing patterns: (1) docs/store.ts uses content hashes for doc_index - good for content-addressable data, (2) issue #570 adds mtime-based tracking for graph_file_metadata - simpler and sufficient for file change detection. Pattern: check stored state → skip if unchanged → update metadata after processing.

CLAUDE_SESSION_ID environment variable does NOT exist - it was our invention. Claude Code only sets CLAUDECODE=1 and CLAUDE_CODE_ENTRYPOINT=cli. Any cross-process state that depends on env vars from Claude Code will fail. Use local session ID generation and temp file communication instead.

Claude Code OOM root cause: progress entries in transcript files store full normalizedMessages (entire conversation history) at each streaming update. This creates O(n²) growth - a session with 1000 progress entries stores the message history 1000 times. This is a Claude Code bug, not controllable by hooks or MCP servers. Workaround: don't resume crashed large sessions, start fresh instead.

The claude-knowledge database is ALWAYS at .claude/execution-state.db (31MB+), NOT in packages/claude-knowledge/data/. The data/ directory only contains external-docs/ for fetched documentation. Empty .db files there are orphans to delete.

Use `graph parse-monorepo` to parse the entire monorepo with cross-package relationship resolution. This creates one ts-morph Project with all files, enabling relationships like openbadges-system calling useBadges from openbadges-ui to be properly resolved instead of marked as external. Running individual `graph parse packages/X` for each package loses cross-package relationships.

Centralized port configuration via Turbo's globalEnv: Define all app ports in root .env (MODULAR_SERVER_PORT, SYSTEM_SERVER_PORT, SYSTEM_VITE_PORT), add to turbo.json globalEnv array, then apps inherit via process.env with fallback to legacy PORT variables. This enables changing one file to update all apps. Always use fallback chains like `process.env.SYSTEM_SERVER_PORT || process.env.PORT || '8888'` for backwards compatibility.

CRITICAL WORKFLOW RULE: Never commit directly to main during /auto-issue, /auto-milestone, or /work-on-issue workflows. "Autonomous" mode removes user approval gates but does NOT remove: branch creation, PR creation, review phase, or any phases. Every code change must go through a PR for user review. Bypassing this breaks user trust and removes their ability to approve/reject changes. The correct pattern is always: Issue → Feature Branch → Commits → PR → Review → Merge.

Beads (Steve Yegge's task management) and claude-knowledge serve different purposes: Beads is for task execution memory with dependency-aware graphs and auto-ready detection; claude-knowledge is for learning persistence and code structure understanding. They're complementary, not competing. The gap in our system is active learning capture - auto-generated commit learnings are low-value; manually captured insights need to become habitual.

Implemented PreToolUse hook for Grep augmentation: when I call Grep with an identifier-like pattern (camelCase, PascalCase, snake_case), the hook automatically runs graph.findEntities() and outputs the results to stderr. This provides passive knowledge injection - I see graph results without having to remember to query the graph. Key insight: fighting training with rules doesn't work; passive augmentation that adds information without blocking is more effective. Session start injection was also disabled since we don't know the topic at session start. Track metrics to see if this changes my graph vs search tool ratio over time.

Session changes for claude-knowledge metrics and knowledge injection:

1. DISABLED session-start knowledge injection (packages/claude-knowledge/src/cli/session-commands.ts:149-152) - The injection happened before we knew what the session was about, making it essentially random. On-demand querying via MCP tools is more useful.

2. ADDED PreToolUse hook for Grep augmentation (.claude/hooks/pretooluse-gate.ts + .claude/settings.json) - When Grep is called with an identifier-like pattern, the hook automatically runs graph.findEntities() and outputs results to stderr. This provides passive knowledge injection - Claude sees graph results without having to remember to use graph tools. Key insight: fighting training with rules doesn't work; passive augmentation that adds information without blocking is more effective.

3. FIXED metrics aggregation (packages/claude-knowledge/src/checkpoint/metrics.ts:getToolUsageAggregate) - Previously only counted tool_usage table (native tools via PreToolUse). Now also includes graph_queries table (MCP graph tools). Accurate ratio: 28 graph / 53 search = 0.53, not 0.

Architectural insight: MCP tool calls don't trigger PreToolUse hooks - they go directly to the MCP server. This means metrics tracking needs to happen in both places: PreToolUse hook for native tools, MCP server for MCP tools.

Skills vs Commands distinction: Skills (.claude/skills/) are read-heavy tools triggered contextually (e.g., pr-review-checker). Commands (.claude/commands/) are multi-phase workflows with state management and error handling (e.g., auto-issue, work-on-issue). New autonomous workflows should use the command pattern.

NEVER use `gh pr merge --admin` to bypass branch protection. When a PR merge is BLOCKED or fails with "base branch policy prohibits the merge", this means CI hasn't completed or checks are pending - NOT that you should bypass. Use `--auto` to queue for merge when checks pass, or wait. The --admin flag bypasses ALL protections including failing CI, and combined with --delete-branch makes recovery difficult if the code is broken. If merge fails, ASK the user what to do. This was learned after bypassing protections without permission and nearly merging broken code to main.

Do NOT use `gh pr merge --auto` flag - it skips review comment validation and merges as soon as CI passes, ignoring CodeRabbit or human review comments. The /auto-merge workflow has a Review Comments step (Step 6) that validates feedback before merging, which --auto bypasses. Wait for CI to complete, check review comments, then merge manually.

Claude-knowledge overhaul plan created after evaluating beads. Key findings: (1) LLM transcript extraction is broken because we generate a random session ID instead of finding the transcript by time range. (2) File-based auto-learnings are garbage (confidence 0.48, "Worked on X: N files"). (3) Commit-based learnings need enrichment with issue context to capture "why" not just "what". (4) Git sync via JSONL export/import enables cross-machine persistence. (5) Session handoff prompts (like beads' "land the plane") provide context for next session. No tech debt rule: When CodeRabbit or any code review identifies issues (even minor nitpicks), fix them immediately rather than deferring. If it can be fixed now, fix it. This prevents accumulation of small issues that become larger problems.

openbadges-ui density system pattern: Components define CSS custom properties (e.g., --badge-list-gap) that density variants (compact/normal/spacious) override. Container styles must reference these tokens using var(--badge-list-gap, var(--ob-space-6, 24px)) rather than hardcoding values, otherwise density settings have no effect on the container.

The `&>` shell redirection operator only silences the command's output, not the job control notifications (e.g., `[1] + done`) that come from the shell itself when a background job completes. To prevent these notifications for 'fire-and-forget' commands in shell hooks (like `precmd`), wrap the command in a subshell `(...)` to isolate its backgrounding from the parent shell. For example, `(command &>/dev/null &)` will run the command in the background within a subshell, preventing the parent shell from reporting its completion.

When running terminal UIs (like Neovim, Claude Code, or other TUI applications), the terminal often enters an "alternate screen mode." In this mode, the application manages its own display and the terminal's native scrollback (e.g., `Shift + Page Up/Down` in Ghostty) is typically disabled. Scrolling within these applications must be handled by the application's internal keybindings (e.g., `Shift + Up/Down` or `j/k` for Neovim/Claude Code).

For modularization of large `CLAUDE.md` system prompts, use rules and skills:
- **`rules/*.md` files (no `hookify.` prefix):** These load automatically and are always active. Ideal for fundamental instructions like frustration detection or core values.
- **`hookify.*.md` files:** These are special rules loaded by a `hookify` mechanism and are *toggleable* via `/hookify configure`. Use these for optional behaviors like a 'learning mode' that guides the user more verbosely, allowing the core prompt to remain concise.
- **`skills/<skill>/SKILL.md` and `skills/<skill>/content.md`:** Skills are only loaded when the AI determines they are relevant to the user's explicit question. This is perfect for storing reference material (e.g., environment details, API documentation) that doesn't need to be in context constantly.

When configuring UI themes, ensure sufficient contrast for interactive elements like selection highlighting. A common pitfall is using colors that are too similar in value (lightness/darkness) to the background, even if they are different hues. The selection color needs to visibly 'pop' while maintaining readability of the text against it. Using a brighter, less saturated accent color is often effective.

When managing configuration with a dotfile manager like `chezmoi`, there are often two layers: template files (the source of truth) and the active configuration (the rendered files). If a manual change is made to an active config file and later a `chezmoi apply` or `theme-switch` command is run, it might revert or overwrite the manual change if not committed to the source templates. Always update the source templates for persistent changes. Additionally, the theme data itself might be managed in a separate file (e.g., `chezmoi.toml`) that needs to be reloaded for applied changes to take effect reliably, especially for applications that get runtime configuration updates (like Neovim with `_G.chezmoi_apply_transparency()`).

If a Neovim keybinding (e.g., `<leader>gg` for `lazygit`) unexpectedly changes behavior, it's often due to a plugin or 'extra' being enabled that overrides the default. Tools like LazyVim allow enabling pre-packaged bundles (`LazyExtras`) which can introduce such overrides. Troubleshooting involves checking plugin configurations and extras to identify and disable the conflicting one. In this case, `lazyvim.plugins.extras.util.gitui` was overriding `lazygit` with `gitui`.

macOS keyboard layout issues, particularly with the `§/±` vs `~/` backtick key, often stem from a mismatch between the detected physical keyboard layout (ANSI, ISO, JIS) and the selected software input source (e.g., U.S., German). macOS stores a single global keyboard type. If an external ANSI keyboard is used with a system configured for an internal ISO keyboard, this can cause key mismatches. Solutions include:
1. Re-identifying the keyboard type via System Settings -> Keyboard -> Change Keyboard Type when the external keyboard is connected.
2. Using a single input source like 'U.S. International' or 'ABC Extended' that supports both `~` and uncommon characters via Option key combinations.
3. Employing a remapping tool like Karabiner-Elements to apply device-specific keyboard modifications.

Karabiner-Elements `device_if` condition is crucial for applying keyboard modifications only to specific physical keyboards (identified by vendor and product ID). This allows for complex setups where multiple keyboards with different layouts (e.g., built-in ISO, external ANSI) can coexist without interfering with each other's expected key behaviors. Using `keyboard_type_v2: iso` globally without device-specific overrides can lead to unexpected key swaps across all connected keyboards.

`pkill` sends a `SIGTERM` (signal 15) by default, asking a process to gracefully quit. Applications can catch and ignore this signal, especially if they are in the middle of an operation (like managing media sessions). `kill -9` sends a `SIGKILL`, which the operating system enforces immediately. Applications cannot catch or ignore `SIGKILL`. When a process refuses to terminate gracefully, `kill -9` is the sledgehammer solution to force its termination.

When designing development environment startup scripts, especially for `tmux`-based setups, prioritize common entry points. Users often struggle with 'how do I even start/attach a session?' over 'how do I create a new pane?'. Therefore, a cheatsheet or script should clearly present session management commands (`tmux new -s`, `tmux ls`, `tmux a`, `tmux kill-ses`) prominently.

When configuring a development environment with `aerospace` and `tmux`, a common pattern for efficiency is to create a single Ghostty terminal window that attaches to a `tmux` session. This allows for all developer tools (shell, Nvim, Claude, various servers) to run within `tmux` windows and panes, accessible from a single terminal application. This reduces the number of separate application windows and streamlines context switching, as seen in the `start-fobizz` and `start-rollercoaster` scripts.

Bloated SQLite databases (`execution-state.db`) and orphaned processes are a significant cause of performance degradation and freezes in long-running applications like Claude Code. SQLite uses file-level locking, meaning concurrent writes from multiple processes (e.g., many AI agents) lead to lock contention, causing processes to wait and potentially hang. This is exacerbated by using 'delete' journal mode (which is less concurrent) and by 'zombie' processes that fail to terminate cleanly, holding open database handles and never releasing locks. Regularly cleaning up stale processes and potentially switching to WAL (Write-Ahead Logging) journal mode can improve concurrency, along with regular `VACUUM` operations to reclaim space.

Running a background command with `&` in Zsh will trigger job control notifications even if output is redirected to `/dev/null`. To prevent these messages for "fire and forget" commands in shell hooks (like `precmd`), wrap the command in a subshell `(...)`.

Terminal applications running in "alternate screen mode" (common for TUIs like Neovim, Claude Code, `htop`) manage their own display buffer and do not use the terminal's scrollback. Standard terminal scrolling keybindings (`Shift + Page Up/Down` in Ghostty) will not work; application-specific keybindings must be used. For Claude Code, `Shift + Up/Down` or `j/k` are used.

When configuring themes with tools like `chezmoi`, there can be a two-layer system: theme *templates* (source of truth) and an *active config* (what's currently applied). A theme-switching script typically copies values from the template into the active config and then reloads applications. It's important to update both the template and then trigger the switch mechanism when changing theme definitions.

Modularizing large prompt definitions (e.g., `CLAUDE.md`) can improve efficiency and context management. Strategies include:
- **Rules files (`.claude/rules/*.md`)**: Load automatically, good for topic-based instructions or always-on behaviors.
- **Skills (`.claude/skills/*/SKILL.md`)**: Only load when the LLM determines relevance, ideal for on-demand reference material like environment details.
- **Hookify rules (`.claude/rules/hookify.*.md`)**: Toggleable behaviors via a command (`/hookify configure`), useful for conditional modes like "learning mode" or "frustration breakers" that are not always desired. Non-`hookify` rules are always active.

When choosing a color for UI elements like selection highlighting, consider the background contrast. A primary color that is too close in value to the background may be invisible. Selecting an underutilized, high-contrast accent color from the theme palette can improve visibility without clashing or competing with other UI elements.

When `chezmoi` manages an application's configuration, changes should ideally be made in the `chezmoi` source templates rather than directly in the generated config. Changes to the `chezmoi` data (`chezmoi.toml`) require an `chezmoi apply` to propagate. If a templated config relies on data that doesn't exist in `chezmoi.toml`, it can lead to templating errors. This highlights the importance of keeping `chezmoi` data and templates in sync.

If a Neovim keybinding (e.g., `<leader>gg` for `lazygit`) unexpectedly changes behavior, it's often due to an installed plugin or extra configuring the same keybinding. Specifically, LazyVim extras (like `lazyvim.plugins.extras.util.gitui`) can override default mappings. Removing the conflicting extra restores the desired functionality.

When dealing with different physical keyboard layouts (e.g., ISO built-in, ANSI external) on macOS, the system's global keyboard type detection can cause issues (like `§` appearing instead of `` ` ``). Karabiner-Elements can resolve this by applying device-specific key remappings using `device_if` conditions to ensure each keyboard behaves according to its physical layout, while keeping input sources for language switching separate.

`Neovim`'s `autoread` feature, which checks for external file changes and reloads buffers, typically requires terminal focus events to be passed through to trigger. If `autoread` isn't working with a terminal (e.g., `Ghostty`), verify that the terminal is correctly relaying focus events to Neovim. LazyVim usually enables `autoread` and appropriate autocommands by default.

When restarting a macOS application or service, if `pkill` (which sends `SIGTERM` for graceful shutdown) fails to terminate it, `kill -9` (which sends `SIGKILL` for immediate, forceful termination) can be used as a last resort. This is particularly relevant for applications handling media sessions (`mediaremoted`) which might resist graceful shutdown.

When creating cheatsheets for tools like `tmux`, prioritize entry-point commands (e.g., `tmux new -s`, `tmux attach`, `tmux ls`) over advanced features (pane management) at the beginning. Most user frustration comes from not knowing how to start or interact with the tool. Starting with common workflow commands makes the cheatsheet more immediately helpful.

When integrating `nvim` plugins and configurations into a `LazyVim` setup, the `extras` functionality is sometimes the intended way to enable popular plugins. If a plugin isn't available as a `LazyExtras` option, it needs to be added manually as a new Lua file in the `~/.config/nvim/lua/plugins/` directory, following a standard plugin specification format (e.g., `packer` or `lazy.nvim` style). Ensure relevant dependencies are also listed.

Bloated `claude-code` project directories (especially `conversations.jsonl` files) can cause performance issues like freezing. Periodically archiving or deleting old, large conversation files and ensuring the `sessions-index.json` is clean can significantly improve responsiveness. The `sessions-index.json` acts as a lookup for conversations; a clean index ensures `claude-code` rebuilds it properly on launch.

Concurrent access to a shared SQLite database using the default "delete" journal mode can lead to significant performance degradation and freezing due to lock contention. This is exacerbated when many processes (e.g., AI agents) are attempting writes simultaneously. Orphaned processes that hold database connections open indefinitely can compound this issue. Solutions include: killing zombie processes, using `VACUUM` to compact large databases, and considering `WAL` (Write-Ahead Logging) journal mode for better concurrency.

When dealing with `claude-code` autonomous workflows, a common pitfall is the accumulation of zombie Claude processes. If a long-running workflow crashes or hangs without properly terminating, the orphaned process can keep a handle to shared resources (like the `execution-state.db` SQLite database). This leads to lock contention for new sessions, causing freezes. Regularly identifying and killing these stale processes is crucial for stability.

Critical limitation: Claude systematically ignores MCP tools and Skills in favor of built-in tools (Grep, Glob, Bash, Read) regardless of instructions, tool descriptions, or CLAUDE.md rules. This is a known issue (GitHub issues #15136, #17902, #19308) that Anthropic hasn't fixed. User built graph tools (graph_find, graph_what_calls, graph_blast_radius) that work well and are better for code navigation, but Claude won't use them. Metrics showed 0% graph tool usage despite explicit "Graph First" instructions. No amount of prompting, aggressive language, or Opus 4.5 best practices fixes this. The user has no way to actually influence tool selection behavior - the levers available (prompts, descriptions) don't control the actual decision. This is deeply frustrating for developers who can identify problems and build solutions but can't make Claude use them. Filed issues go ignored while Anthropic focuses on new models. The irony: Anthropic created MCP to extend Claude, but Claude ignores MCP tools.

To test AbortController timeout behavior: create an Error with name="AbortError" and have the mock fetch reject with it. This mimics what AbortController.abort() produces when a fetch times out. Example: const abortError = new Error("aborted"); abortError.name = "AbortError"; fetch = mock(() => Promise.reject(abortError));

When cleaning up test files (especially SQLite with WAL mode), only ignore ENOENT errors, not all errors. Permission or lock errors should surface to prevent flaky tests. Pattern: `if (error.code !== "ENOENT") throw error;`

Tests that scan real user directories (like ~/.claude/projects/) can be flaky on machines with many entries due to filesystem ordering and slice limits. Prefer test isolation using temp directories or environment variable overrides for the base path.

Inconsistent error handling philosophies within a codebase create debugging challenges. api-providers.ts throws on errors (caller must handle), while llm-extractor.ts silently returns [] (graceful degradation). Document the philosophy in JSDoc so callers know what to expect.

Only ignore `ENOENT` (file not found) errors when attempting to delete files in test cleanup routines. Other errors like permissions or locking issues should be re-thrown or handled explicitly, as they indicate a real problem rather than an expected absence of a file. Silently catching all errors can mask critical issues.

Tests that scan real user directories (e.g., `~/.claude/projects/`) and apply limits (e.g., `MAX_PROJECT_DIRS`) are susceptible to flakiness. These tests can fail intermittently depending on the user's local file system state, especially if the number of actual directories exceeds the test's assumed limit, causing critical test files to be excluded from the scan. It's safer to use temporary directories or allow the base directory to be overridden via an environment variable for better test isolation and reliability.

Inconsistent error handling philosophies within a codebase (e.g., some functions throw clear errors, while others silently return empty arrays or default values on failure and only log warnings) can lead to significant debugging challenges. While silent failure might be intended for graceful degradation, it blurs the line between an actual empty result and a failed operation. It's crucial to document the chosen error handling philosophy using JSDoc (or similar documentation) to clarify expected behavior and aid in debugging.

When testing `AbortController` timeouts, the most effective way to simulate a timeout is to create an `Error` object with its `name` property set to `"AbortError"`. Then, configure mock functions (e.g., `globalThis.fetch`) to reject with this specific error. This accurately mimics the error produced by `AbortController.abort()` when a network request or other subscribable operation is cancelled due to a timeout, ensuring the test covers the correct error handling path.

Autonomous agents, especially for code generation and review, can operate more effectively when given a clear, sequential workflow with defined phases, each producing specific artifacts. This structured approach, including explicit checkpoints and task tracking, enables better recovery from interruptions, facilitates quality gates, and provides user control at the PR stage. Skipping phases or direct commits bypasses these benefits and can lead to increased token usage, bugs, and manual reverts due to lack of a structured review and verification process. See [github.com/AnandChowdhary/continuous-claude](https://github.com/AnandChowdhary/continuous-claude), [github.com/erans/autoagent-action](https://github.com/erans/autoagent-action), and [github.com/Codium-ai/pr-agent](https://github.com/Codium-ai/pr-agent) for examples of structured AI agent workflows for code.

Integrating a task tracking system with clear `blockedBy` dependencies for each phase of an autonomous workflow provides a crucial visualization of progress and enforces the intended sequence. While checkpoints remain the source of truth for the workflow's state, task lists offer a user-friendly interface to monitor ongoing operations and understand dependencies. This is particularly useful for complex multi-phase operations where agents are delegated specific responsibilities, as shown in projects like [github.com/irgolic/autopr](https://github.com/irgolic/autopr) and [github.com/avivl/cloud-sre-agent](https://github.com/avivl/cloud-sre-agent).

The AI's ability to follow explicit instructions in system prompts (like ignoring local command messages) is unreliable and can lead to it generating irrelevant or unhelpful acknowledgements, even when explicitly told not to. This is a known issue from web search results [github.com/anthropics/claude-code/issues/7621] and [github.com/anthropics/claude-code/issues/1357].

The AI's internal tooling (claude-knowledge) is not being consistently utilized for code exploration, insight storage, or prior learning querying, despite explicit instructions and its own stated intent. This suggests a disconnect between designed functionality and actual AI behavior, possibly indicating a need for more robust prompting or internal mechanism adjustments to ensure tool use. The AI explicitly acknowledges this as a 'problem is me' scenario.

When testing `AbortController` timeouts, mocking a hanging promise with `new Promise(() => {})` combined with asserting a rejection that matches `/timed out/` is an effective pattern. To simulate the `AbortError` specifically, create an `Error` object with `name = "AbortError"` and have the mock reject with it.

When handling file cleanup in tests (e.g., deleting temporary database files), it's crucial to only ignore `ENOENT` (file not found) errors. Other error types, such as permission errors or lock errors, should be re-thrown to surface potential issues with the test environment or test setup. This improves test resilience and catch real problems early.

Tests that scan real user directories or rely on global filesystem state can be inherently flaky, especially when limits (e.g., `MAX_PROJECT_DIRS`) are involved. If a user's environment exceeds these limits, the test might fail non-deterministically. Solutions include using temporary directories for isolation or providing environment variables to override base directories for testing. This is a known issue documented in [github.com/anthropics/claude-code/issues/1339] regarding `.claude` discovery.

Inconsistent error handling philosophies within a codebase (e.g., throwing detailed errors in one module vs. silently returning empty arrays and logging warnings in another) create significant debugging challenges. A consistent approach, clearly documented, helps users understand when an operation truly failed versus when it simply yielded no results. Using discriminated unions for return types can explicitly convey success or failure, avoiding ambiguity.

Project management tools like the AI's internal milestone planner can identify potential conflicts in development workflows, such as new feature development preceding foundational work (e.g., new UI components being built before a robust token-first theming system is in place). Recognizing and addressing these dependency chains early can prevent significant rework. The tool effectively identified a dependency chain of `tokens contract` -> `refactor to hooks` -> `Tailwind preset + docs` -> `migration notes`.

Turbo globalEnv limitation: Environment variables defined in root .env and listed in turbo.json globalEnv are only inherited when running via `turbo dev` from root. Apps started directly (e.g., `bun run dev` from app directory) don't get these values. Solution: Always set fallback values directly in each app's .env file, even when using centralized config.

Port configuration for monorepo apps: Turbo's globalEnv only passes root .env variables when running via `bun dev` from monorepo root. When apps are started directly (e.g., via tmux scripts like start-rollercoaster), each app needs PORT explicitly set in its own .env file. The modular server uses PORT=3666, openbadges-system expects to connect to it at that port via OPENBADGES_SERVER_URL.

When running multiple applications in a monorepo, especially with tools like `bun dev` or `tmux` to manage individual application processes, environment variables defined in the root `.env` or passed via a global configuration (e.g., `turbo`'s `globalEnv`) may not be inherited by sub-processes if they are started directly from their respective directories. Direct execution of `bun run dev` within an application's directory will only load that specific application's `.env` file, bypassing any root-level environment configurations. To ensure consistent environment variable loading, either explicitly source the root `.env` before running each application (e.g., `source $PROJECT_DIR/.env && bun run dev`), or define fallback/explicit values directly within each application's `.env` file for critical variables like `PORT`.

When using `tmux` to manage multiple application processes, environment variables sourced by a parent script in the main `tmux` session are generally *not* automatically inherited by new shell sessions created for individual `tmux` panes. Each `tmux` pane initiates a new shell session, which typically requires environment variables to be set explicitly within the command executed in that pane or by sourcing an `.env` file within the pane's command itself. Relying on root-level `.env` files for individual processes within `tmux` panes without explicit sourcing can lead to configuration mismatches between local development and other environments (e.g., CI/CD, staging servers).

When centralizing port configuration (e.g., using `MODULAR_SERVER_PORT=3666` in a root `.env` file) for multiple microservices, it's crucial to ensure that all execution paths (e.g., local development, `bun dev` from root, individual `bun run dev` commands, CI/CD, staging) correctly consume this central configuration. If an application's `.env` contains a comment indicating where a variable *should* come from but doesn't define a fallback, it creates a silent failure point where the application will use its default port if the external variable isn't provided. Explicitly setting `PORT=3666` in `apps/openbadges-modular-server/.env` provides a robust, self-contained configuration for that specific service, mitigating issues arising from inconsistent environment variable propagation.

JSONL import deduplication must check for existing entities by BOTH content_hash AND id. When content_hash is null or doesn't match, must still check if ID exists before INSERT to avoid UNIQUE constraint violation. Handle by either skipping (if existing is newer) or updating (if import is newer).

JSONL import deduplication design decision: When entities have matching content_hash but different IDs, we update the existing entity's data but preserve the original ID. The imported entity's ID is discarded. This is intentional - we prioritize content identity (content_hash) over entity identity (ID) for deduplication. Document this behavior for users.

JSDoc comments inside inline TypeScript object types can break parsing when the comment text contains `*/`. For example, `/** Include packages/*/docs/ (default: false) */` causes a parse error because the `*/` in the glob pattern `packages/*/docs/` is interpreted as closing the JSDoc comment block, leaving the rest as invalid syntax. This produced 17 cascading TS errors (TS1131, TS1005, TS1128, etc.) starting at the comment line. Fix: use `//` line comments instead of `/** */` JSDoc comments for inline properties in function parameter types. JSDoc block comments are safe in interface declarations and top-level positions, but risky inside inline object type literals when content may contain `*/`.

The planning graph adopts a "pull, not push" design, meaning explicit commands like `/plan status`, `/goal`, and `/done` are used to interact with the work plan rather than automatic context injections. This is a deliberate choice to prevent token wastage and provide context on demand, avoiding information overload. This contrasts with a system that might automatically update based on observed actions.

The core mental model for the planning graph is a stack, similar to a call stack in programming. Goals and interrupts are pushed onto the stack, and finishing an item (via `/done`) pops it off, resuming the activity beneath it. This provides a clear, hierarchical view of active and paused work.

When an item is popped from the planning stack (`/done`), it triggers a summary of the completed work. This summary is then stored in the knowledge graph as a learning. This feature, inspired by the 'Beads' concept, keeps the active stack lean while preserving historical context and learnings. This means that a history of discrete, completed work units is automatically built.

Drift detection in the planning graph operates on a purely factual basis. Instead of making judgments, it reports discrepancies between stated goals and actual development activity (e.g., commit counts on different branches). This is described as a "neurodivergent-first design," providing visibility and data without imposing guilt, acknowledging that development work is often non-linear.

The planning graph and a proposed "learning graph" leverage the same underlying infrastructure (SQLite + JSONL). This indicates a strategic reuse of the architecture for managing different types of hierarchical, stateful information within the AI assistant's domain.

Performing `/done` when a PR is created (and awaiting review) rather than when it merges is presented as a 'practical' option. The rationale is that the planning stack tracks *active focus* rather than code lifecycle. This allows the developer to promptly context-switch and work on other tasks while a PR is pending, effectively managing their individual workflow.

Manual management of the planning stack (e.g., using `/done` explicitly) produces better summaries. The context available during the manual `/done` operation allows the AI to generate a more informed and relevant summary of the completed work, which is then stored in the learning graph. If actions were auto-triggered, this rich context might be lost.

The `/work-on-issue` command implements a supervised, gated workflow with 4 hard gates requiring explicit user approval at each phase. This ensures strict control and transparency during complex development tasks, preventing the AI from proceeding without human oversight at critical junctures. This is an explicit 'Human in the Loop' design pattern.

The workflow systematically creates all related tasks (e.g., for each gate) upfront but uses `blockedBy` dependencies to enforce sequential execution. This provides a full progress visualization immediately after setup while ensuring that phases are completed in the correct order. Tasks are supplementary for UI, with checkpoints remaining the source of truth.

Within the `/work-on-issue` workflow, there's a strict rule to "Show, don't summarize" at gates. This means the full, verbatim content of issues, plans, or diffs must be presented to the user for review. This prevents loss of detail or misinterpretation through AI summarization, ensuring the human reviewer has all necessary information for approval.

The design of `tokens.css` utilizes a three-tier token architecture: Foundational, Semantic, and Component. This creates a clear hierarchy where Semantic tokens reference Foundational ones, and Component tokens reference Semantic ones. This promotes reusability, consistency, and easier maintenance of the styling system. Key decisions include using `var()` references for cascading dependencies and backward-compatible aliases for existing components.

During the token refactoring, the `themes.css` file was updated to only contain theme class overrides, with the `:root` definitions moved to `tokens.css`. This separates global token definitions from theme-specific adjustments, adhering to a single responsibility principle for CSS files. Careful consideration was given to import order to maintain the correct cascade.

A decision was made to preserve hex colors rather than switching to OKLCH for token definitions because the primary goal of the task was to establish token *structure* and *public API documentation*, not to perform a color format migration. This highlights a pragmatic design choice to scope changes and focus on the most impactful aspects of the task.

When faced with a last-minute requested change to a CSS token prefix (e.g., `ob-` to `rd-`), the assistant advised against implementing it within the current PR. The reasoning included the large scope of the change across the codebase, potential breakage for existing consumers, and the benefits of separating concerns. The recommendation was to handle it as a distinct, follow-up issue with a proper migration plan, demonstrating a focus on clear PR scope and maintainability.

The `docs/theming.md` comprehensively documents the token architecture, including: explanations of the 3-tier model, public token reference tables, custom theme examples, built-in themes, how to create custom ND themes, runtime theme switching, and accessibility guidelines. This centralized, detailed documentation is crucial for maintainability and external adoption.

The `--ob-` prefix, while tied to an `openbadges-ui` package, was debated for a potential `rd-` (rollercoaster.dev) prefix. The decision to keep `--ob-` was based on alignment with the package name, existing codebase references, and the potential for a large, disruptive rename. The reasoning suggests that project identity can be expressed at higher levels (org/repo/brand) rather than solely within low-level CSS prefixes of a domain-specific library. Issue #594 - CSS Token Contract Implementation Summary:

Created three-tier token architecture (foundational → semantic → component) in tokens.css for openbadges-ui. Key learnings:

1. LEGACY ALIASES ARE CRITICAL: Components use short-form names (--ob-gray-*, --ob-error, --ob-primary-dark) that must be aliased to new --ob-color-* foundational tokens in :root. Without these, components silently fall through to hardcoded fallbacks and theme overrides break.

2. FONT IMPORT ORDER: fonts.css must be imported before tokens.css in BOTH entry points (main.css via @import and index.ts via JS import). tokens.css references --ob-font-system defined in fonts.css. Missing fonts.css from index.ts caused ND themes to silently lose accessibility fonts.

3. AVOID DUPLICATE DEFINITIONS: Don't redefine font family variables in tokens.css when they already exist in fonts.css. Use aliases instead (--ob-font-sans: var(--ob-font-system)).

4. THEME COMPLETENESS: Every semantic token defined in tokens.css should be overridden by every theme class. Popover, input, card tokens were missing from several themes. Use a checklist approach.

5. COMPONENT TOKEN PATTERN: Every documented component should have centralized --ob-{component}-* tokens in tokens.css. Components reference these tokens instead of defining local vars with hardcoded fallbacks. This enables theme switching via the cascade.

Resolved: "Investigate Gemini extraction failure". Root cause: LLM extractor sends combined transcript payload (8+ MB from 6 files) to OpenRouter → HTTP 413 Payload Too Large. The session-end hook's 60s timeout makes it the wrong place for LLM extraction. Designed heartbeat replacement: background process spawned at session-start, watches transcript file, counts message lines (user/assistant type only), triggers Gemini extraction every 30-50 new messages. Key findings: transcript files are append-only (compaction appends summary lines, never truncates), subagent transcripts are separate files in {session}/subagents/ (not in main transcript), existing Learning Capture footer in all agent files can be strengthened to push subagent insights into main transcript. The AI assistant needs to be explicitly prompted to verify previous actions, even if it claims to have completed them. The AI needs to recognize when external tools (like GitHub CLI) are not authenticated and adapt its plan, rather than failing silently or assuming success. The `systematic-debugging` strategy emphasizes that *before* attempting any fixes, especially when under pressure or when a quick fix seems obvious, the root cause must be thoroughly investigated. Violating this core principle often leads to wasted time and new bugs. This involves carefully reading error messages, reproducing consistently, checking recent changes, gathering evidence in multi-component systems, and tracing data flow. The approach provides structured phases: Root Cause Investigation, Pattern Analysis, Hypothesis and Testing, and Implementation. A critical rule is that if three or more fixes have failed, it's a strong indicator to question the underlying architecture rather than continuing with incremental fixes.

SSH connection issues over VPN often stem from complex network configuration changes introduced by the VPN, such as altered routing tables, DNS servers, or firewall rules. Common culprits include full-tunnel VPNs blocking all traffic through the tunnel, VPN firewalls blocking outbound SSH on port 22, DNS resolution changes leading to incorrect server lookups, routing conflicts, or server-side IP whitelisting. Rapid diagnostic steps include pinging the server while on VPN, running `traceroute`, connecting by IP instead of hostname, trying alternate SSH ports, and checking routing tables. Solutions may involve split tunneling, alternative SSH ports, bypassing DNS issues, adding static routes, or configuring server-side IP rules. [devproblems.com](https://www.devproblems.com/ssh-connecting-via-vpn-fails-how-to-fix/)

`ClientAliveInterval` (SSH-level keepalive) is a more reliable mechanism for detecting dead SSH sessions and keeping NAT mappings alive than `TCPKeepAlive` (OS-level). `ClientAliveInterval` sends probes over the encrypted SSH channel, verifying the session's liveness, while `TCPKeepAlive` operates at the OS raw TCP level and can be easily spoofed or blocked by firewalls. The default `ClientAliveInterval 0` (disabled) combined with high packet loss (millions of TCP retransmissions) leads to silent connection drops. Configuring both server-side (`ClientAliveInterval` in `/etc/ssh/sshd_config.d/keepalive.conf`) and client-side (`ServerAliveInterval` in `~/.ssh/config`) is crucial, as either end can be affected by network timeouts.

Bun (and potentially other runtimes using `dlopen()`) extracts native `.node` modules to `/tmp` at runtime. This poses a risk on systems like macOS, where `periodic` cleanup scripts or reboots can remove these temporary files while the Bun process is still running or has them memory-mapped. This can lead to crashes like `EXC_BREAKPOINT (SIGTRAP)` when the running code attempts to access a now-missing memory region. A robust solution is to set the `BUN_TMPDIR` environment variable to a persistent location (e.g., `$HOME/.cache/bun-tmp`) to ensure these critical files are not prematurely deleted. [github.com](https://github.com/oven-sh/bun/issues/20753)

When refactoring components to use CSS custom properties (tokens) and removing hardcoded fallbacks (e.g., `var(--ob-color, #FFF)` to `var(--ob-color)`), it's critical to ensure that the CSS defining these tokens is correctly loaded in all environments where the components are rendered. A common pitfall, as seen with Histoire (a component playground), is that the component preview environment might not implicitly import all necessary global CSS files (like `tokens.css` or `fonts.css`). This was masked by the original hardcoded fallbacks, which provided a visual default even if the `var()` didn't resolve. Removing fallbacks exposes this underlying configuration oversight more clearly, necessitating explicit imports in environments like `histoire.setup.ts` to ensure tokens are defined. If the underlying package bundles its styles, such redundancies are unnecessary.

When performing token-based styling refactors, removing hardcoded fallback values for CSS custom properties (`var(--token, fallback_value)`) can expose underlying `HMR` or setup issues in component Storybook/Histoire environments where `tokens.css` might not be explicitly loaded. This leads to styles disappearing, which is a visible failure that helps identify the root cause in the build setup. Conversely, keeping the hardcoded fallbacks would mask these issues, leading to silent degradation. This reinforces that token-only styles are generally safer as they fail visibly, allowing for quicker debugging.

For robust token coverage testing of Vue components in a monorepo, a custom test utility was developed using Node.js `fs` module to recursively find `.vue` files and extract their `<style>` blocks. This was necessary because typical bundling tools like Vite don't expose glob patterns easily for direct file system traversal, and `glob` module itself was not available in the testing context. The test then asserts against hardcoded values (hex, rgba, px for spacing/border-radius) and checks for deprecated class prefixes (`manus-`). This shows a pattern for creating targeted, custom static analysis for style-related regressions.

When dealing with `--ob-` prefixed CSS custom property use within Vue components, ensuring consistency for local custom properties is crucial. The existing `BadgeClassList.vue` used `--badge-class-list-*` which should be updated to `--ob-badge-class-list-*` to align with the global token naming convention. This prevents confusion regarding the scope and origin of custom properties, making the stylesheet easier to maintain and understand within a token-driven system.

HTML semantic elements should be used for accessibility. For instance, if a card element is interactive, it should explicitly include `role="button"` to inform assistive technologies. Similarly, tab navigation requires `role="tablist"` and proper keyboard navigation handling for accessibility. Overlooking these details can severely impact user experience for individuals relying on screen readers or keyboard-only navigation.

When refactoring class names in Vue components, especially with `:deep()` selectors, it's vital to ensure *all* references (including those inside `:deep()` for child components) are updated. A manual fix was required for `:deep(.manus-badge-class-card)` after automated agents missed it, highlighting that automated refactoring tools might not catch all nuanced CSS selector patterns.

When using Playwright for visual regression testing or automated UI verification in a headless environment (like a Mac Mini without a GUI), `browser_install` and `browser_close` might be necessary to reset the browser state, particularly if previous attempts to launch or navigate timed out. Directly navigating to sandbox iframes (`page.goto('http://localhost:6006/openbadges-ui/iframe.html?id=stories-component--default')`) instead of through the Histoire UI can prevent complex navigation challenges and improve reliability for screenshots.

When creating a new test file, ensure its location aligns with the project's test runner configuration (`vitest` in this case). The initial placement in `src/styles/__tests__/` instead of `tests/unit/styles/` caused it to be ignored. Similarly, be mindful of the `git add` paths when working from a package subdirectory in a monorepo; paths must be relative to the current working directory, not the monorepo root.

The `getLocalizedString` utility exists centrally at `@utils/localization` and supports various input types (string, array, object) and language preferences. Developers should import and use this shared utility instead of copy-pasting its implementation. When migrating, note that the shared utility returns an empty string for missing values, so callers should adapt from `getLocalizedString(value, fallback)` to `getLocalizedString(value) || "fallback"` patterns.

A common anti-pattern in Vue components: `isFocused` reactivity state and associated `onFocus`/`onBlur` handlers were found to be dead code across multiple card components. The focus styling was already handled purely by CSS `:focus-visible`, making the JavaScript state machine unnecessary. Regularly auditing for unused reactivity can streamline components.

CSS custom property names should use consistent kebab-case (`--ob-badge-list-empty-color`). Using BEM-like double underscores (`--ob-badge-list__empty-color`) within custom property names is non-standard and can lead to confusion, as custom properties are not CSS selectors.

List components handling pagination (`BadgeList`, `IssuerList`) should always guard the `pageSize` prop against non-positive values (e.g., `Math.max(1, props.pageSize)`). Failing to do so can lead to `totalPages` calculations involving division by zero or infinite loops if `pageSize` is 0 or negative. This guard should ideally be implemented using a computed property like `effectivePagePageSize`.

When using CSS custom properties with fallbacks, ensure the fallback is *reachable*. A common pitfall is redundant fallbacks (`gap: var(--badge-list-gap, var(--ob-space-6))`) where the second variable (`--ob-space-6`) would only be used if `--badge-list-gap` is *not defined*, not if it's empty. If `--badge-list-gap` is always defined, the second fallback is unreachable.

Redundant CSS rules or media queries should be removed. Duplication of base rules (e.g., `display: flex;`) or media queries that precisely duplicate existing, broader rules, indicate dead code or inefficiencies. Linting and code analysis can help detect these.

The Vue.js style guide states that Single-File Component (SFC) filenames should consistently use either PascalCase or kebab-case. PascalCase is preferred for better autocompletion integration, though kebab-case is acceptable to avoid case-sensitivity issues on some file systems. [vuejs.org](https://vuejs.org/style-guide/rules-strongly-recommended.html)

Base components, which apply app-specific styling and conventions without containing global state, should use a consistent prefix (e.g., `Base` or `App`). This helps organize them alphabetically in editors, improves discoverability, and avoids arbitrary naming for simple wrappers. [vuejs.org](https://vuejs.org/style-guide/rules-strongly-recommended.html)

For projects using a build system, each Vue component should reside in its own file. This improves findability and maintainability of individual components. [vuejs.org](https://vuejs.org/style-guide/rules-strongly-recommended.html)

The autonomous agent workflow emphasizes a structured approach with distinct phases (Setup, Research, Implement, Review, Finalize) and artifacts produced at each stage (branch, plan, commits, PR). This design provides recovery points, quality gates, and user control through the final PR, avoiding direct commits to `main`.

An 'autonomous' workflow doesn't mean skipping steps, but rather executing all defined phases sequentially without user approval gates between them. Explicit flags like `--skip-review` or `--dry-run` are provided for intentional modification of behavior within the workflow.

The workflow incorporates a task tracking system that integrates with the checkpoint system. Tasks are created upfront after Phase 1 and updated as the workflow progresses. `blockedBy` relationships between tasks (`TaskUpdate(task, { addBlockedBy: [previousTask] })`) are used to enforce and visualize the workflow sequence, providing progress visualization to the user.

The workflow separates concerns into specialized agents for each phase (e.g., `setup-agent`, `issue-researcher`, `atomic-developer`, `review-orchestrator`, `finalize-agent`). This modularity improves maintainability and allows each agent to focus on a specific, well-defined task. This directly aligns with the 'Agent Orchestration' and 'Agentic Workflows' concepts of breaking down complex tasks into subtasks handled by specialized agents. [kroolo.com](https://kroolo.com/blog/agent-orchestration), [digitalocean.com](https://www.digitalocean.com/community/conceptual-articles/build-autonomous-systems-agentic-ai), [github.com](https://github.com/githubnext/agentics)

The `issue-researcher` agent analyzes the codebase using graph queries and checks dependencies before creating a development plan. This 'understand before acting' approach aims to reduce token usage by preventing trial-and-error coding, which is a key token-saving strategy.

The `atomic-developer` agent is designed to make atomic commits for each step of the implementation plan, running validation after each commit. This ensures that changes are small, reviewable, and that issues are caught early in the development process, aligning with best practices for version control and debugging. This also aligns with principles presented in the Kiro autonomous agent documentation where agents create feature branches and make atomic commits with clear messages. [kiro.dev](https://kiro.dev/docs/autonomous-agent/github/)

The `review-orchestrator` agent can auto-fix critical findings, with up to three attempts for each. This proactive remediation reduces the need for manual intervention and improves workflow efficiency, making the process more autonomous. When auto-fixes fail, the system escalates to the user, providing options for continuance, force-PR, or abort. This is a robust error handling strategy for an autonomous system.

A `.claude/dev-plans/issue-<N>.md` file is used to store the development plan generated by the `issue-researcher`. This provides a persistent artifact for the plan, allowing subsequent agents (like `atomic-developer`) to follow it and providing a record for debugging or review.

The workflow integrates external notifications (Telegram) for key events like workflow completion, PR creation, and escalation scenarios. This keeps the user informed without requiring constant monitoring of the workflow's internal state.

The wave orchestrator uses `Bun.file().writer()` for logging, which buffers output in memory. Logs are only flushed to disk when the process exits, making real-time monitoring (`tail -f`) of in-progress tasks impossible. This creates a UX problem where processes appear stuck or without output. The fix is to use `Bun.spawn()` with `stdout`/`stderr` directed to a file descriptor for immediate writes, or to implement periodic flushing.

When an agent process appears frozen (e.g., high uptime but no CPU usage and no active network connections), it's likely stuck in a non-responsive state. The most effective resolution is to kill the process and rely on the orchestrator's `--resume` or checkpointing mechanism to restart or pick up where it left off. The checkpoint system can be used to determine the last successful action.

Using `claude -p` to spawn sub-processes can sometimes prevent them from being indexed in the main agent's session history, making it harder to locate their conversation files directly. Alternative methods, like searching for recently modified session files around the process start time, become necessary.

Running large-scale autonomous workflows (like entire milestones) in a single session can lead to 'exponential conversation growth' and memory issues due to large JSONL conversation files. Implementing a strategy to archive old or completed conversations, especially large ones, is crucial for maintaining performance and stability.

When an autonomous workflow orchestrator performs a `--resume` command, it should include robust checks beyond just the lack of a PR. Specifically, it needs to verify: 1) if an existing feature branch or worktree contains previously committed work for the issue, and 2) if the checkpoint system indicates active progress or completed work on a different branch by a prior execution. A simple re-execution can overwrite existing work or lead to redundant efforts.

Despite a `--resume` operation potentially creating a new worktree or branch, the checkpoint system should retain knowledge of previous commits related to an issue, even if they were on a different branch from an earlier, failed, or interrupted run. This allows for manual recovery, such as creating a PR from the previously successful branch, even if the current resumed execution is not progressing.

Autonomous agents (like Claude Code 2.0) should be designed with checkpoints and multi-stage workflows to provide structured progress, recovery points, and quality gates. This minimizes token usage by preventing trial-and-error, allows for early bug detection, and provides user control through PRs. The architecture emphasizes that 'autonomous' means no user approval *between phases*, not a complete bypass of the workflow integrity (e.g., no direct commits to main).

When designing an autonomous workflow, create all workflow tasks upfront and use a `blockedBy` pattern to enforce and visualize the sequential execution of phases. This provides immediate progress visualization and ensures the correct order of operations, even if tasks are supplementary to the primary checkpoint system. Task metadata should link to the checkpoint for debugging.

Implement an escalation mechanism for autonomous workflows when critical findings remain unresolved after review. This mechanism should notify the user with options to continue (manual fix then re-run review), force-PR (create PR with flagged issues), or abort. This maintains user control and provides clear recovery paths for agent limitations.

For robust autonomous agent workflows, integrate with GitHub through GitHub Apps. This allows the agent to clone repositories into an isolated environment, create feature branches, make commits (co-authoring with the user), and open pull requests with detailed descriptions. The agent should only act on repositories where the GitHub App is installed and authorized, and only for users with write permissions.

A common pitfall in autonomous systems is when an issue is accidentally resolved manually (e.g., PR merged), but the agent's workflow for that issue remains active or in a failed state. The autonomous system should be capable of detecting this `already completed` state by checking for existing PRs, their merge status, and corresponding commits on the target branch. This avoids redundant work and resolves false-positive failures.

Pytorch's MPS backend does not support bfloat16, only float16 and float32. Attempting to use bfloat16 will result in a TypeError. The recommended solution is to use `torch.float16` for quantization compute dtype when using `BitsAndBytesConfig` on Apple Silicon Macs, or fall back to `float32` for general operations if `float16` is not sufficient or desired. [openillumi.com](https://openillumi.com/en/en-pytorch-mps-bfloat16-error-fix-mac/), [github.com](https://github.com/pytorch/pytorch/issues/104191)

For PyTorch on Apple Silicon (MPS), `torch.autocast` is primarily designed for CUDA and mixed precision training. It should be skipped or conditionally enabled only for CUDA devices, otherwise, issues may arise. Similarly, `torch.cuda.amp.GradScaler` is also CUDA-specific and should be disabled when running on MPS. [runebook.dev](https://runebook.dev/en/articles/pytorch/mps)

While PyTorch's MPS backend allows leveraging Apple GPUs, `torch.compile()` (or `torch.jit.script` in older versions) for performance optimization is still experimental or less reliably supported on MPS compared to CUDA. It's often safer to skip `torch.compile()` when targeting MPS unless specific compatibility has been verified. [runebook.dev](https://runebook.dev/en/articles/pytorch/mps)

When setting up PyTorch on systems with various accelerators (CUDA, MPS) and CPU, it's best practice to implement a device detection logic that checks for CUDA first, then MPS, and finally falls back to CPU. This ensures portability and optimal performance across different hardware configurations. Using `torch.backends.mps.is_available()` is the recommended way to check MPS availability at runtime, which checks if MPS is both built into PyTorch and compatible with the current system. [runebook.dev](https://runebook.dev/en/articles/pytorch/backends/torch.backends.mps.is_built), [runebook.dev](https://runebook.dev/en/articles/pytorch/mps)

For JSONL files during a merge conflict where both branches add new, distinct lines, the resolution strategy should be to keep all new entries from both branches. This is the most logical approach when the additions are independent and non-overlapping. The task then simplifies to removing conflict markers (`<<<<<<<`, `=======`, `>>>>>>>`) while preserving all unique JSON lines. [github.com/articles/resolving-a-merge-conflict-using-the-command-line](https://docs.github.com/articles/resolving-a-merge-conflict-using-the-command-line), [github.com/articles/resolving-a-merge-conflict-on-github](https://docs.github.com/articles/resolving-a-merge-conflict-on-github), [github.com/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pull-requests/addressing-merge-conflicts/resolving-a-merge-conflict-using-the-command-line](https://docs.github.com/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pull-requests/addressing-merge-conflicts/resolving-a-merge-conflict-using-the-command-line), [github.com/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pull-requests/addressing-merge-conflicts](https://docs.github.com/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pull-requests/addressing-merge-conflicts), [articles.mergify.com](https://articles.mergify.com/resolve-merge-conflicts/)

When resolving merge conflicts in a JSONL (JSON Lines) file, the key insight is that each line is an independent record. Therefore, if conflicts arise from both branches adding different entries, the resolution should involve keeping all entries from both branches, effectively concatenating the additions. Standard merge conflict markers (`<<<<<<<`, `=======`, `>>>>>>>`) need to be manually removed, but the content of the lines themselves should be preserved. This differs from conflicts in code blocks where only one version of a specific line or function can be kept. [github.com/articles/resolving-a-merge-conflict-using-the-command-line](https://docs.github.com/articles/resolving-a-merge-conflict-using-the-command-line), [github.com/articles/resolving-a-merge-conflict-on-github](https://docs.github.com/articles/resolving-a-merge-conflict-on-github), [github.com/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pull-requests/addressing-merge-conflicts/resolving-a-merge-conflict-using-the-command-line](https://docs.github.com/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pull-requests/addressing-merge-conflicts/resolving-a-merge-conflict-using-the-command-line), [github.com/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pull-requests/addressing-merge-conflicts](https://docs.github.com/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pull-requests/addressing-merge-conflicts), [articles.mergify.com](https://articles.mergify.com/resolve-merge-conflicts/)

The autonomous agent workflow (`auto-issue`) follows a strict, sequential multi-phase process (Setup, Research, Implement, Review, Finalize) to ensure structured progress, provide recovery points, enforce quality gates, and offer user control before merging. Skipping phases without explicit flags (`--skip-review`, `--dry-run`) is considered an anti-pattern, as it bypasses critical review and control mechanisms.

The workflow integrates with a task system for progress visualization. All tasks for the entire workflow are created upfront after the 'Setup' phase, but their status is updated sequentially as each phase completes. This `blockedBy` pattern in task creation ensures that the visual representation of progress clearly shows dependencies and the workflow order. While tasks provide UI, the 'checkpoint' remains the source of truth for the workflow state, making the task system supplementary and resilient to task operation failures.

In autonomous mode, if the 'Review' phase (orchestrated by `review-orchestrator`) finds unresolved critical findings, the system escalates by notifying the user (via `telegram` skill) and offers explicit options: `continue` (re-run review), `force-pr` (create PR with flagged issues), or `abort` (delete branch). This mechanism provides a supervised autonomous approach, where the system proceeds without interruption unless critical issues are detected, giving the user control only at critical junctures.

The `issue-researcher` agent analyzes the codebase using 'graph queries' and checks dependencies before creating a development plan. This pre-computation step aims to prevent trial-and-error coding by understanding the context upfront, which the system claims 'reduces total token usage' and leads to a more efficient implementation phase.

The `atomic-developer` agent is designed to implement changes step-by-step, making 'atomic commits' for each step. Validation is run after *each* commit. This fine-grained approach makes individual changes easier to review and, if validation fails, allows for targeted inline fixes rather than monolithic rollbacks.

For specific workflow modifications, the system uses flags like `--dry-run` (stop after research, show plan), `--force-pr` (create PR even with unresolved issues), and `--skip-review` (bypass the review phase). These flags allow for targeted behavior changes within the established workflow, rather than requiring users to manually bypass phases, which aligns with the workflow integrity principles.

The concept of 'agentic workflows' is a research area being explored by Microsoft Research and GitHub Next. These workflows, written in natural language markdown, are transformed into GitHub Actions executed by AI agents (e.g., Copilot, Claude, Codex) in containerized environments. They emphasize secure by default operations with read-only permissions and explicit `safe-outputs` for write operations. [microsoft.com](https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/research/project/agentic-workflows/) [github.com](https://github.com/githubnext/agentics)

Several projects explore similar concepts under different names. 'AutoPR' [github.com](https://github.com/irgolic/autopr) runs AI-powered workflows over a codebase, including features like living summaries and custom YAML actions. 'AutoAgent-Action' [github.com](https://github.com/erans/autoagent-action) is a composable GitHub Action integrating AI agents like Cursor CLI and Claude Code for running prompts in PR workflows. These indicate a growing trend in using AI to automate complex development processes within CI/CD pipelines.

AI coding agents from OpenAI, Anthropic, and Google leverage Large Language Models (LLMs) trained on vast text and code data. Researchers are improving LLM deficiencies by using techniques like 'simulated reasoning models' to generate context and 'reinforcement learning from human feedback (RLHF)' to refine instruction following and tool use. [arstechnica.com](https://arstechnica.com/information-technology/2025/12/how-do-ai-coding-agents-work-we-look-under-the-hood/)

When performing merge conflict resolution in JSONL files where the intention is to keep all entries from both branches, the cleanest approach is to remove conflict markers and retain all valid JSON lines. This avoids data loss from either side of the merge.

A common bug pattern in status tracking or counting systems involves multiple counting phases that are not mutually exclusive. This can lead to double-counting. The solution is to restructure the logic to first identify interdependent states (e.g., 'blocked'), and then perform a single, comprehensive counting pass for all statuses, ensuring mutual exclusivity (e.g., `done + inProgress + blocked + notStarted = total`).

Local transient test failures, especially those involving I/O or database corruption (like SQLite test databases), might not indicate an actual code bug if CI/CD pipelines pass. These can be specific to the local environment and should be investigated locally rather than assumed to be a code issue. [claudelog.com](https://www.claudelog.com/claude-code-changelog) and [github.com/anthropics](https://github.com/anthropics/claude-code-action/labels/p1) show examples of issues that can arise with test setups, such as `SDK crash with AJV error` and `Code reviews keep timing out`.

For robust unit testing, especially with complex systems involving resolvers or external dependencies, it's crucial to implement a dedicated mocking mechanism (e.g., a test helper to inject mock resolvers). This allows for precise control over dependency behavior, leading to stronger assertions and isolating the code under test effectively. Early open-source agents often struggled with predictable test generation without such mechanisms, as noted in [engineering.atspotify.com](https://engineering.atspotify.com/2025/11/context-engineering-background-coding-agents-part-2).

When an agent is informed that a PR has been merged by the user during an ongoing rebase operation, it's important for the agent to adapt its workflow. Instead of attempting to rebase the already merged PR, it should acknowledge the user's action and proceed with the remaining tasks, such as rebasing other dependent PRs.

Model Context Protocol (MCP) servers, such as those for Git (to manage branches/merges) and GitHub (for repository control), are essential tool integrations for AI assistants. They provide capabilities like reading repository history, creating commits, and handling merge conflicts. Without robust integrations, actions like rebasing and conflict resolution would be significantly harder for an agent. [developertoolkit.ai](https://developertoolkit.ai/en/claude-code/quick-start/mcp-setup/) provides details on setting up these servers.

When managing multiple concurrent tasks (like fixing comments on several PRs), an effective strategy is to handle each task sequentially while keeping the user informed of the progress and specific actions taken on each. This helps manage complexity and clarify which issues have been addressed. [github.com/badlogic](https://github.com/badlogic/claude-commands) highlights workflows for managing multiple tasks, including those with full isolation using git worktrees.

The transition from fixing review comments to performing rebase operations indicates a structured approach to PR lifecycle management. First, address the feedback to ensure code quality; then, rebase against the main branch to integrate changes and resolve conflicts before final merge, ensuring a clean history.
